I'm sure that ya'll have seen the other reviews talking about how 'waah, they removed 90% of the content' and so on in regards to the new Seamless World update. Allow me to explain a bit, so you can see why this isn't actually a problem. Originally, the game had one island you would start on, with a limited world-space. However, you could build portals to traverse to new island worlds. It worked a little like how Minecraft handles going to the nether, except it was other islands. Each was their own biome, with a decent bit of variation in enemies and resources.

What this Seamless World update did was get rid of that world style. Instead, they changed it so that, instead of a bunch of small worlds that you used portals to go between, you instead have one large landmass that you can explore and adventure on much like Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild or Genshin Impact has. They did leave out a large chunk of features from the game when they made the switch however, and this is what people are getting hung up on.

Simply put, the content is not GONE, but rather rearranged. Some things are in the game and people just don't realize that they are because they have yet to encounter them, either due to rarity, placement, or other things. As for the rest, they wanted to get this update out so we could play and enjoy it as soon as they could. This meant that, even though not all of the content from those island biomes had been placed in the world, we're getting it much sooner. In other words, the some 30% of things that aren't in the game currently are only not in the game for a temporary length of time while they work on fitting them into the new design, since disjointed island biomes are very different from the far more continuous and connected design of the new world. Just give it some time, and it'll all be back.

~~~~~~

In conclusion, it's a very fun game, and definitely worth picking up. The asking price of ~$25 is honestly a steal in my opinion, and, if you can get it on sale, even better. It has fun mechanics and, even though it isn't super well written, a rather funny story. The combat generally feels pretty fluid, striking somewhere between a soulslike and the aforementioned Breath of the Wild. Lots of RPG elements, such as levels, varied equipments, potions, skill trees, etc. And you can even use the monster taming system to basically play Pokémon instead of the normal fighting, if that's more your speed.

Frankly, this game has just about everything, and is definitely a hidden gem. Could not recommend more. :)

The endgame boils down to one thing: crafting good gear. This will make or break your experience. The crafting in this game is an elusive mechanic, and I will attempt to describe it to you so that you can better understand it before going in.

[h1] Now, one might ask, "What is possibly wrong with an incentive to craft in a game called Craftopia?" [/h1] 
The problem(s): A completely RNG driven crafting system. The difference between a base item and one with good enchantments is so astronomical that you should almost never consider using a base item over one with enchantments (exception would be a weapon with high base attack or magic attack). 

[b] Enchantments work like this: [/b] Enchantments are tied to proper words. These proper words each reflect a set of stats and can be incorporated into items through crafting materials. For instance, if an iron ingot has the proper word "Crimson" and is used to craft a sword, then the sword has a chance to receive the proper name, "Crimson" and the stats associated with the name. 

As far as I have seen, an item can hold up to four enchantments. For example an item is called "The Never Ending Sky's Ancient Veteran Griffin's Broadsword", and it has the four enchantments: "The Never Ending Sky's", "Ancient", "Veteran", and "Griffin's". Without the enchantments, a broadsword would just be that, a broadsword. On paper this system sounds really fun and interesting, but in practice the crafting is tedious and can feel completely unrewarding because of two things: no indication of success chance (or tutorial explaining the chances involved with enchanting items), and inventory management.       

[h1] Now, one might ask, "How is crafting RNG if the inputs always guarantee the outputs?" [/h1] 
The problem(s): The inputs only guarantee the base item being produced. Enchantments are, as far as I can tell, completely randomly assigned each time an item is crafted. The possible name of the item produced is pulled from the crafting materials used to produce it. I'll repeat: having crafting materials with proper names does not guarantee that crafted items will have those proper names. It is entirely possible to use a significant amount of very rare crafting materials to produce a white/common/base item! 

This is a HUGE problem when some items require dozens of crafting materials to produce just one unit. The rudimentary experience I've had with the crafting is something around 1 in 75 to 1 in 50 (~1.33% to ~2% chance) to produce an item with 4 proper names. 

Enchantments or modifiers distinguish items and crafting materials from each other. Unless an item has the same enchantments and base item, then it will not stack with items with similar bases. This leads into problems with inventory (and storage) management. Frankly, I think this problem mostly stems from the lack of inventory slots (not carry capacity), and I think it can only be resolved by introducing something like a backpack or a straight upgrade to storage/item slots. 


[h1] I will not leave the developers out on a limb here. Here is how you improve your game: [/h1]
Display roll chances for enchantments when crafting; also, improve the chances to craft said loot. People do not have the time (or patience) to slog through hours of gameplay only to come up with a white/common/base item. That leaves a really sour taste in your player's mouths and you want them to feel good about crafting gear with the loot they EARNED. 

Increase player inventory and storage SLOT amounts (not carry capacity per slot) to alleviate the item bloat that inevitably happens in the endgame. 


If none of this has dissuaded you from jumping into early access, then you'll like the game. I had fun with it myself, but I cannot earnestly recommend it to everyone in its current state.

I'm a game developer. Last year, I spent 40 minutes in a call explaining how this game had accidentally solved one of the biggest problems in open world level design: The feeling that there's plenty to explore, but not much incentive to do so. The enchanting system, at that time, was accidentally genius. Why "accidentally?" Because these guys can't make anything that isn't buggier than a $200 New York apartment. And yet they'd implemented a series of integrated systems that would set the player out on a journey across 10 biomes to do something as mundane as harvesting wood... I'd be fighting dragons in Hell just to get a bundle of logs with a "More Scorching" enchantment. There wasn't just a big world, but there was this integral reason to want to go everywhere, even if your goal for today was small and specific like "craft a new shield upgrade."

Then they dropped this Seamless World Update.

Ignoring that the bugs are far worse than I remember, across every field (animation hangs, armor clipping, AI just outright breaking or running an infinite loop (even teleporting back to the start and repeating after each loop) etc.. But no, they took the one thing they'd done exceptionally and made it the most mundane, "20 minute a day" mobile grind you could imagine:

Know how you get enchantments now? Open Map. Teleport to dungeon door. Fight easy boss. Get a pile of 1 time use scrolls, containing random enchantments. Repeat. Mindlessly. For eternity. Just spam the exact same fight, over and over and over..

And while you're at it: be aware that the seamless world update REMOVED bosses (approximately half of all existing bosses if not more), REMOVED 2 out of 7 ages (the end-game progression arcs) and REMOVED MOST (At least 70, probably more likely 90%) of enemy types. Content from two years ago is no longer present.

So basically, they watered down the best mechanic they had, removed the best part of the game, removed a good portion of bosses, bugged it all to hell and back (sadly Hell no longer exists) and lost all of their unique individuality that made this game stand out despite being programmed in such a buggy, poorly optimized, amateur way, all to make it a more "digestible" variant of so many nearly identically pointless games where you just loop the exact same behavior over and over with no real reason or incentive to do so.

As a programmer, artist, animator, and everything else.. I am entirely self taught. So it's pretty bad that I can so openly criticize the implementation this badly. Because with all of 3 years of experience, I don't have a single prototype that's as badly programmed as this whole game.

I enjoyed it despite that. Then returned to see what the Seamless World update would add. I'm sorry, but I see nothing worth recommending since that update. Everything good was removed and replaced with the most watered down, restricted, repetitive version you could possibly imagine.

Oh, and they removed most of the build system's snap and placement logic, too. You can't change the voxel size for building placement anymore. Just one poorly planned giant grid and nothing else.

This review has been edited multiple times, and was initially a negative review. With the release of the Seamless Map Update near the end of June 2023, however, I'm quite happy to finally make this a positive review. As I type this, I'm still very early in the game, so I don't know if it's worth a full 25 dollars yet, but if it isn't already, I'm highly confident that it will be someday, if future updates are as beneficial to Craftopia as the Seamless Map update has been. I may update this later on as I proceed through the game, but in the interest of keeping this updated review short but still getting my opinions across, let's go over what I've perceived as the ups and downs of the new and VASTLY improved Craftopia.

THE GOOD:
+The combat overhaul has made combat fairly interesting. Perfect dodges and counterattacks aren't a particularly revolutionary thing, but it's a bit of spice Craftopia's combat desperately needed.
+At least in the early game, Craftopia has a much better sense of focus, and gives the player a non-zero amount of actual instruction on how to get into the core gameplay loop.
+The world is satisfying to explore; I got lost in Geezah Peninsula for several minutes at one point and had the most fun I've had being lost in a long time. I'm looking forward to getting lost again in the future.
+In old Craftopia, getting guns and tamer skills was more of a mid/lategame thing, but now both are accessible pretty early in the game. Combined with skill resets seeming to no longer cost gold, you're now much more free to experiment with different builds.

THE BAD:
-Crafting at the very start of the game feels a bit too restricted. I feel like the player should at least get access to copper crafting before finishing the Geezah Tower, perhaps by unlocking the recipes after bringing copper ore to Camille?
-I wasn't going to talk about technical faults like bugs in this review, but this one deserves a special mention. The motorcycle, which is on the title screen and given to you by Camille for finishing the tower, has a lot of trouble traversing the new terrain for some reason. I know this will be patched, probably sooner rather than later, but considering the apparent focus the devs have put on this specific vehicle, I feel like this shouldn't have been an issue in the first place when the update launched.
-That's it. Just those two negatives.

I was a fan of the ideas behind Craftopia when the I first got my hands on the game, and seeing the Seamless Map Update release both renewed my interest in the game and definitely made it feel more like the game I imagined when I first got it. Great work on the update, devs.

What a pleasure this game is.

It feels like Breath of the Wild had a child with No Man's Sky and tried to teach that child the importance of The Elder Scrolls Morrowind.

As a base, the game takes a little too much from BotW, But at the end of the day, it feels like it was supposed to be mechanically anyway. Get gear, level up, craft equipment, fish, climb, cook, sell... It just feels natural. Combat is exactly what you would expect, except the part where being Link felt grounded, when the going gets rough, you can bolt away from most things and glide away, as it has two speeds. 
-It also mixes mechanics so well that if you like one concept or another, you can play on those strengths until you get the skills or gear you need to either feel comfortable with the combat, or feel comfortable with the crafting and equipment mechanics. 
-Overall, it feels like they targeted a lot of the quips people have had with crafting games such as, bad combat, areas being too large, carrying weight being too cumbersome, moving inventory to stores taking too long, etc. It isn't small, but it also isn't too big, but if you want more there are so many areas you can visit, and if you want less all you have to do is make money and get enough materials to press into new areas... Just watch your stats, you might get mowed down if you go too far.

Now, allow me to explain why the similarities are what they are in my opinion.
-The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild
Obvious... But running, exploring, combat, gliding, dungeons, loot, inventory UI, even some of the things they are going to add feel like someone loved BotW so much that they wanted to pull everything they could get away with while adding their own personal touches, even some things like skulls the goblins hide in and the excessive amounts of scout towers they look out from feels verbatim to say it lightly, heck, even the way Link gained hearts or stamina by visiting shrines is in here. But when you like something so much, but just want to add your personal touch to it, I would imagine a fan wanting to go about it the same way. Frankly, the games mechanics work so well with the feel of BotW that you might want to forgive them for borrowing a little too liberally at times, though I hope they find better ways to do so, because it feels a little overdone sometimes.

-No Man's Sky
The game spreads itself around locales that has varying levels as you progress, and as you progress, you can take any and all materials you pull from the environment aside from the door you use to leave the locale you're in and the one you arrive on. There are differing environments, habitats, enemies and resources that you can harvest, and even capture monsters and NPCs that you can bring with you across locales to build the perfect instance of whatever ecosystem you would like to have. This addition to the gameplay design allows a lot of forgiveness for the otherwise small building area, but also leaves so much untouched potential for things like survival, and randomly generated islands to take on with your friends, or alone. You could even try to be timed on how long it takes you to get to the god's alter from scratch, and get on a leaderboard or whatever. Regardless, this mechanic is basically the band aid that makes the game stronger than it should ever be if used properly.

-The Elder Scrolls: Morrowind
Now... Morrowind fans might get a little bit irritated at why this is here, but with the addition of traited equipment as well as equipment that grants a spell on it that you can cast when equipped, the game has the potential to be so intricate that it can be utterly broken in the best of ways. 
For example, equipment has a chance to adopt traits from materials to used to craft it. Normally that means using various materials and hoping that those traits get adopted, to the point where a few tries of rare equipment could expend the materials altogether. But if you make a bucket, or a ring, or an arrow... You could get those same powerful effects without having to lose your mind over the chance normally required to get those things to happen. So now your equipment bag is full of arrows, buckets and rings that allow you to adjust your character without having to flip your blacksmith desk. Far out right?! I hope they never change this. 

-Another fantastic thing about this game is the automation potential, you can breed animals you catch, mass produce crops and have robotics manage your areas with some know how. Even have mechanizations deal with ore deposits (bedrocks) that are otherwise futile to mine physically. If you have the need to do more things, there are options there that provide you the tools to automate everything you need if you get the materials to make it all. 
-There is also no weight system, so if you set out with the goal of getting ore, each item type can hold four stacks of items of its own type, and supports different inherited values too. So if you got tired of how long it took for you to move your ore and wood in other games... Just come here and play this one. You can carry like 5000 logs. I hope they up the amount of equipment space you have though, and add support for dying clothes. As it is now there are only 8 armor sets. 4 for each gender, and 4 of which are just recolors of the different two types for each gender. There are supposed to be vanity clothing coming... I'm very excited for that too.

Well, there are a few gripes that I do have, but they might not be that serious. 
-In crafting games, investment is almost necessary, maybe actually necessary. So when you buy a spell for the first time and use it, and consider starting over because you know if you put those two points into jumping you would jump twice as high, it gets pretty annoying. Do yourself a favor and try skills with a throwaway character so you don't get burned by a bad description, or a bad skill overall. They said they were using a translation thing to translate, so, it is what it is.
-Sometimes fighting an enemy over the course of a long time might make them disappear between night or day. I remember fighting a dragon and not being particularly ready offensively, and ended up watching it go up in smoke when the day was over... It might be a mechanic so you don't catch enemies you aren't technically ready for, but it freaking sucks when you go back to your base and have to sell off all the weapons you just wore down trying to fight that thing... Maybe it was a bug, but Christ if there are more challenging fights later on, I really don't want to be mechanically told that I either have to only fight things I can plow through or not even try. I beat it after I did the Morrowind thing above. But I won't expect that to be possible with future enemies.

Should you get it? I'm not sure... For me, I told myself that I wanted something like Genshin Impact to waste away on, but I lost all interest in it after I saw it was free-to-play. I played a few other crafting games like Dark and Light, and Citadel Forged in Fire, and while some of those have more intricate item gathering mechanics, and bigger maps as well as a more tolerable fast traversal option. (the hover boards are super clunky in here...imo, didn't make the others yet) Overall, this one feels the most like a game that you happen to be able to build in, instead of a game you build in, that happens to have exploration. Though I will say that other survival games handle traveling in the dark a little better. But if I'm honest, unless Monster Hunter, Lost Planet or Dragon's Dogma make a survival game with all of their mechanics intact, it'll be hard to top the limitless potential this game has. If you're like me, sure, give it a go. But if the games that come together to make a game like this satisfy you on their own? Come back when regular people are playing the game on YouTube, and draw your conclusions from there.

I can't wait to see what they do next. Don't let us down.

I normally don't write reviews, But for this product I thought I would. 

Before I dive in, I also wish to add, [b]Hamatchi is not required for multiplayer.[/b] You just need the host to port forward their router. There are many guides on the internet for this if you have not done this before. The defualt port for Craftopia is 8787.

My experiences were through multiplayer, and while I had some glitches and bugs, none of them I encountered were devastating. I should also note this review I'm writing is after 3 hours deep of gameplay, and while that may not be much, I feel like it is enough to evaluate the game to some degree. 

[b] .:Aesthetics:. [/b]
Firstly the aesthetic of the game are fantastic, from a visual sense it reminds me of breath of the wild. I personally found the music to get annoying after awhile as it was on a constant loop and sounded low quality (coming from a bit of an audiophile). So I simply turned that off. Some of the animal sounds also seemed off. Such as the deer, didn't sound like a deer to me, though this is a minor flaw. There really isn't anything I can complain about visually, and I didn't encounter any issues or bugs with graphics. The interface is standard of an RPG, easy to understand so there's not much more you can ask for in that regard. 

[b] .:Performance:. [/b]
The game ran alright, At 1440p my fps were almost always ~60 (capped at 60) with a 8700k, 1080 TI. Sometimes they'd drop a little into the 50's. This title can be demanding on your graphics card depending your resolution and graphics card choice. At the current moment their graphics settings are rather simple in terms of customization or optimizing your performance. The best you can do is downscale resolution and disable antialiasing, so some additional graphical options would be a great improvement for players.

[b] .:Gameplay:. [/b]
Gameplay is fun, melee combat is movement based with wide sweeps, jump attacks, and charge attacks (additional attacks and skills can be unlocked) it feels very classic-like. the combat felt familiar, such as titles like Ratchet and Clank. Magic seemed to be blended with melee and range, as those weapons also offered bonuses to magic attack. I'm unsure if there's specific magic weapons, but with what I've seen if you were to go pure magic the best stat stick is the best sword you can get your hands on. This gave magic more of a supportive, side class feel rather than one of the trinity (melee, ranged, magic).

[b] .:Building:. [/b]
Building is simple, not that I feel it needs to be complex, but it has floors, walls, ramps, conveyors, and simplistic automation. Your autonomous devices mostly serve as a quality of life, and still require player interaction somewhere along the line. 

[b] .:Progression:. [/b]
Progression is short, but also fun. With 3 hours I'm at stage 4 out of 5 (There are currently only 5 stages released, but there are more planned). Even though each stage expands on the grind and the requirements to progress, I found it's still pretty fast progression. This is alright for me, as I'm fine making my own goals in a sandbox environment, such as going out and discovering things rather than focusing on gathering and crafting. I plan on investing a lot more time in the title later, but I'm waiting for a few hotfixes and patches before progressing further. It's obvious in-game that they plan to expand it much more. 

[b] .:Exploration:. [/b]
While progression is short currently, exploration seemed to have many places to go. This game isn't open world entirely, but instead you can travel to new maps, with different level design, monsters, and resources. The zones seem to have a level recommendation, though I did not check if you need a level requirement to move to a new tile. You would definitely have a harder time if you went underleveled though due to enemy scaling.

[b] .:Glitches:. [/b]
There were some glitches I've encountered, while I wasn't host in the multiplayer session, I encountered a fair amount of desyncing. Enemies that were there for me, but not for host. Boss went into a lazer attack, died for host, but never stopped firing the lazer. Host got stuck in a default pose, no animations. (re-equipping armor fixed that) and host had a couple of UI bugs that a quit to menu and relaunching the session fixed.

[b] .:Do you recommend the game?:. [/b]
This game is very much "early access" If you're willing to be a early adopter, and enjoy what the game has to offer, while it isn't alot. it's still substantial and there's alot of fun to be had. If you're looking for a in-depth experience I think it'd be best to wait and see where development goes and what Pocket Pair adds. There are quite a few skills, and some weapons/items that show in the menus but are locked out labeled, "coming soon". Past that, I have no idea of their direction, it's too early to tell. But as is; It is a game with a hand full to things to do, places to explore. And I will admit an enjoyable one.

TL:DR: There are many aspects to this game. So many that I can confidently say there is likely something for everyone. However nearly every single aspect to Craftopia is incomplete. Another reviewer described Craftopia, "As wide as an Ocean, as deep as a puddle." This sentiment is spot on.

OK, the long version. Craftopia is a survival sandbox esq, rpg esq, experience. Like some other games of similar nature you have Characters and you have Worlds. They exist separately. Character options and World options are fairly common. Each world is composed of a series of "islands". You must locate islands of certain types, at certain distances from the origin (this is referred to as "levels"), in order to obtain certain resources. Should you discover all of your islands of a level range you are SOL until you reach endgame. The only way to replace an island is using late to end game recipes. Islands with the same name are identical. There is no apparent randomization as to the content of an island. The level of the mobs, and the loot is determined by the level of the island. Each island has some dungeons on it (except empty islands). Dungeons come in a couple of varieties. Zone dungeon (some mobs then a boss). Mine dungeon, these have resources of the appropriate level plus clay, rare ore, coal, lime stone, and a couple of others that may not occur outside of mines, at the end of the mine there will be a boss fight. Challenge Dungeons, in a challenge dungeon you are challenged to complete a task, kick a ball into a hoop, escape a maze, complete an obstacle course, no boss fight, but loot at the end. Basically you explore an island, collect resources, go up levels, unlock high level islands, repeat.
Right now you may be thinking, "Ok, that sounds like fun for a while" I will admit that was me when I bought the game. Here is the kicker. In order to unlock higher level islands, you need to consume some ingredients. The ingredients required change from level to level, and may not be consistent from world to world (more investigation required to confirm). The first 5 levels of islands are relatively easy to unlock. I go to an island, gather a bunch, clear the dungeons, then return to my home base to process loot. Here is where things break down fast. If you are not on an island, nothing on that island continues to function. This means that while I am out exploring my crafting jobs are not running, my animals are not populating or [spoiler] pooping (which you need a crap load of btw) [/spoiler]. Which means that I then need to spend a couple of hours at my base waiting for crafting to finish so that I have the ingredients for the next age or island. This is fine a good for a while. There are many other things that can distract us ADD brain people. However, after a while all that is left is to stare at the crafting station and wait for it to finish. For those that are thinking "but there is automation!" I say not really. There are mechanisms that may allow for crafting tasks to be chained, but the players must be on the Island for those to run. Which means, in mutiplayer, you have a number of frustrated players that all want to go hunt the next boss(es) but are stuck waiting for ingredients. Then, once you do have your ingredients it rolls on a random table to generate islands. Which means it is very possible to generate 6 empty islands in a row. Which then means more HOURS of afk crafting, or collective waiting. 
The automation tools that do exist seem like they came as several different asset packs from the Unreal marketplace, and they were strapped together with duct tape. They may work, they may not, depending on how you set things up. The automation tools are also significantly larger, provide no additional throughput, but may allow for afk crafting.

Aside from the core mechanics above, there are three general combat styles Melee (receives most love), ranged (seems like they almost forgot about this), and magic. In my time playing I made sure to explore each of these. Melee has the most options. I can add skills for 1h + shield, 2h, dual wield, or fists (unarmed). There apear to be unique options for 'katanas' which are different from other weapons. Ranged combat made it a bit easier to learn some boss mechanics. Ranged combat does require ammunition, does the least DPS, and has the least skills associated. Magic offers a wide array of options. You can be a dedicated damage caster with damage spells, AoE, single target, dot, multi-target, you have a bunch of options. You can augment a melee or ranged build with some spells. Like chance to not consume ammo for a time, healing, or melee attacks increase the damage of your next damage spell. I strongly suggest that every player use the starting dodge skill, and heal. There is no content that I have completed where these two skills did not help. 
Boss fights are fairly simple. they have slow, obvious mechanics that should be easy to dodge (with dodge skill). Despite that they move very erratically which means ranged attackers should expect to do 10-40 damage to a boss or a few hundred on the rare weak spot or critical hit. While Magic casters are consistently ~300dps throughout the fights, and melees may be on again and off again for large damage. Overall I think the game would be better if the devs focused on the island exploration, and dungeon mechanics, and either removed or reduced the age mechanic.

There are vehicles at this time. They are super janky and will explode for little to no reason. With two exceptions. The raft, which is virtually useless (its too slow), and the helicopter. The helicopter is an excellent way to explore a map and scout areas while avoiding significant dangers. The hover boards, buggies, and motorcycles were hard to control effectively or would over react to physics in destructive ways. There seem to be a few more vehicles but after 88 hours in I still have not experienced them.

At this time I do not recommend Craftopia. Its a janky garage project that is woefully incomplete. You can lose a dozen or two hours into easy, but you are not likely to have enjoyed that time, or be made better for that time investment.

Fantastic game. Got this a while ago and at first the multiplayer barely worked, but with subsequent patches (the devs are working hard on it) this improved and became playable.

Game has a lot of depth to it and found time after time there was an additional layer of complexity after ascending ages, or figuring out new mechanics with gear, or skill trees. The game gets even better with friends as you can actually make a composition of tank, heal (kinda) and dps, and I definitely reccommend this game to be played with friends.

The sweet spot seems to be 4 people, especially if you pick different roles, more than that and gear fighting becomes a thing as it is incredibly material consuming and RNG to get 1 set, let alone 4. Going over 4-6 people becomes a bit of a mess, especially when magic gets involved. One ice spell is particularly frustrating as it interacts with players and creates a very large impassable obstruction which can interrupt healing, abilities or trap you. The combat itself, while relatively deep for melee with a lot of different routes to take whether you want to go in hard with damage or tankyness, a lot of builds are viable, though there is an annoyance with archery where you are effectively "losing" a gear slot (arrows) due to firing them. 

The netcode is the game's main weakness, and this ties in heavily to combat. While I would say combat is "fun" it can be pretty frustrating with hit detection, animation lock, and ESPECIALLY in multiplayer having everyone seeing consistent results in the same combat. Often when doing a boss with a lot of abilities, different people will see abilities used on different people, or at different times, but only one or the other will be "real." The game's netcode seems to be a bit of a mess, though it's understandable for a beta game.

I have come across a few serious bugs and issues though (mostly to do with netcode) and the main one that comes to mind is where I made the mistake of building on land at ground level on the starter island. Me and a bunch of friends built a very nice and large base which Alexa very nicely decorated and arranged with chests, but due to one stray blue blob creature getting stuck undernearth, the game decided it had enough. A load of lag and audible hit detection later, I came back to the base to see that a hole had been blown from the base, all the way through multiple floors, taking out our entire chest room with it, from one small mob which got bugged in the wall, destroying half of the base. Suffice to say I've built high in the air or over water ever since.

When you get to the "endgame" you start to really notice some of the game's other flaws. While at first, dungeon variation seems pretty nice with multiple dungeon types and different end bosses on each map, by the time you've run a few they will quickly get stale and repetitive, and you have to run quite a few of these for materials, gear and stat upgrade tokens. The maps have a similar issue, where you feel like the game has endless variation until about 10 or so hours in, when you realize there's about 10 different map types repeated, leading to knowing the map's layout as soon as you arrive. All in all, the game is very rough around the edges and needs a lot of development, but with friends this game is really a 9/10 and a great laugh. Just don't let Maddie near any open flames or she will set everyone and the whole base on fire.

Also dragons are cool as hecc. If you can look past the growing pains of this game, and understand it will get much better with time, then this is an easy buy.

Content

Combat

Building
Very simplistic. You can snap to a grid, and there is a check box on my screen to turn that off but I can't figure out how to check i!. Duel Language
According to some of the notes within the game, there are elements of the game that has not yet been translates into English from Japanese. That's fine. It necessitates the building of a base, some fortifications, and encourages you to prettify your abode with select items that have a direct impact on your gaming experience via buffs. 
Craftopia lacks this.
I found myself just throwing down benches to make the resources requisite for the next advancement in age, as there is no real benefit to building structures. The next age unlocks more things, but also teases what else there is to unlock in the next, which just tempted me back to making what I needed to unlock that. [h1]Seamless World Update[/h1]

With a heavy heart, I have to dish out harsh criticism for one of my favorite games.

[b]---- Short version ----[/b]
[b]Con:[/b]
- Seamless World Update has changed the game feel a lot, and the new graphics style is not everyone’s cup of tea
- Dungeons are tedious, monotonous and uncreative. The dungeon bosses and their drops are always the same
- Quests take away the appeal of exploring and freedom from the game. The story is unnecessary and annoying
- Map is very monotonous in the biomes and mobs. There is hardly any new content or surprises
- Crafting has taken a back seat. The old system with different materials and bonuses was clearly superior
- Game is full of bugs that spoil the fun. The version can hardly be called early access

[b]Pro:[/b]
- Saveable skill builds
- Improved control of vehicles
- Proper climbing is now possible
- Map has some nice details and buildings

[b]---- Full version ----[/b]
The Seamless World Update is more or less a completely new game and has not much to do with Craftopia anymore. The graphics style may be a matter of taste, but it does not suit my taste at all, it looks more like a Zelda rip-off to me.

[b]Dungeons:[/b]
The dungeons, as far as I have seen so far, seem to be more or less the same, much longer and stricter in terms of the solutions. For example, by invisible barriers that prevent shortcuts. As a compensation for the length, there is an interface with “challenges” where you start directly in the boss chamber. This leaves no room for creativity. Also, the dungeon bosses seem to be fixed, we will come to the drops in general later.

[b]Quests:[/b]
To be honest, I don’t know what a story has to do in Craftopia. The quests stifle any explorer instinct in the bud. Wasn’t it once a core of Craftopia to explore and discover secrets? Since the update, you are sent by NPCs to the necessary materials to level up with a map marker, to the next dungeon etc. You run more or less from map marker to map marker.

[b]Map:[/b]
The map itself is very nicely designed, but unfortunately not very varied, neither in terms of biomes nor mob diversity. Very well done, on the other hand, are some lovingly designed buildings, villages and small fortresses. The map could have great potential if it were filled with more variety and a certain dose of randomness. Unfortunately, there is practically hardly any new content, the tried and tested is scattered over most of the map, so you are not really surprised for many hours and can’t discover anything new.

[b]Drop & Crafting:[/b]
Crafting feels like it plays only a minor role, which is somehow ironic for a game called Craftopia. If you like, you can of course build a base as usual and have fun there, but when it comes to equipment, you are relatively quickly at the end equip. Farming special materials in the different biomes to get the matching bonuses on the EQ falls completely by the wayside. Instead, you get scrolls in dungeons with random bonuses on them that you can use to enchant equipment accordingly. In my opinion, this is a complete misdecision, as the old system was an absolute unique selling point of Craftopia.

[b]Bugs:[/b]
Well, here I don’t even know where to start. The version is so buggy that you can hardly call it early access. Even the unstable alpha of the previous version was much more bug-free than this update. I can only speculate that there was possibly pressure to use the Steam Summer Sale with the update, but releasing a version in this state is more than questionable. 
To name a few examples of bugs:
-Sometimes mobs don’t die when their HP drops to 0 (if that happens with a dungeon boss, very annoying because you can’t get out of the dungeon normally without killing the boss)
-Pets somehow get lost (run around aimlessly, glitch through the floor sometimes)
-In multiplayer bosses consistently ignore all players except the host
-Sometimes dismantling becomes impossible while building
-The head glitches through all helmets so far (you can hide the helmet but that’s unfortunately also buggy)

But not all changes are worse, so what has improved:

[b]Skill system:[/b]
There are now more skill points and free skill reset, and the best improvement in my opinion is the ability to save/load skill builds. The slots for saving have to be bought, and each change of the build costs something, but that is a good balance since you can now reset for free. The skills themselves have also been visually revised in part, which I think is quite well done in contrast to the general graphics style. The only point of criticism here is the magical shield, which is unfortunately much too over-present (brightly glowing) and just annoying at night.

[b]Controls:[/b]
Especially the control of vehicles has been improved significantly, the hoverboard for example can now be driven really well. You can also climb normally now.

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
I still see great potential in Craftopia despite all the difficulties. The developers have already shown once that they are capable of developing a great game concept. I hope that they will reintegrate many old features in upcoming updates. After all, they react quickly to the numerous bugs and deliver almost daily current updates with fixes. I haven’t given up on Craftopia yet and hope that the team will respond to the feedback from the community.

Currently I can’t recommend anyone the state of the game and hope that we will keep the legacy version before the Seamless World update for a long time, even though I am aware that this Craftopia is unfortunately dead. But maybe something better can come out of the new Craftopia with a little more time, as long as the criticism from the community is taken seriously.

[b] ---- Kurzfassung ---- [/b]
[b] Con:[/b]
- Seamless World Update hat das Spielgefühl stark verändert, und der neue Grafikstil ist nicht jedermanns Sache
- Dungeons sind langatmig, monoton und wenig kreativ. Die Dungeonbosse und ihre Drops sind immer die gleichen
- Quests nehmen dem Spiel den Reiz des Entdeckens und der Freiheit. Die Story ist überflüssig und störend
- Map ist in den Biomen und den Mobs sehr eintönig. Es gibt kaum neuen Content oder Überraschungen
- Crafting ist in den Hintergrund gerückt. Das alte System mit verschiedenen Materialien und Boni war deutlich überlegen
- Spiel ist voller Bugs, die den Spielspaß trüben. Die Version ist kaum als Early Access zu bezeichnen

[b] Pro:[/b]
- Speicherbare Skillbuilds
- Verbesserte Steuerung von Fahrzeugen
- Richtiges Klettern ist jetzt möglich
- Map hat einige schöne Details und Bauwerke

Craftopia is like a teenage relationship. It's fun, it's exciting, you get an overwhelming feeling of anxiety when apart. Yet, it's also immature and prone to missteps ultimately leading to frustration.

As of the time of this review what you're getting with Craftopia is jack of all trades master of none experience. You've got exploration (albeit on limited sized islands). You've got dungeons and rpg elements (albeit simple dungeons and imbalanced skills). You've got base building (albeit with limited options and janky placement). You've got automation (albeit still needing a lot of hand holding and hit or miss success).

I think you get the idea and this runs through nearly all elements of the game, an initial WOW factor and then just under the surface the deficiencies become apparent.So why the positive review? Well of course this is Early Access and you do have a solid foundation here to build a game upon. While the entry price is high for an Early Access title in this state I, personally, weighed up the risk of the game never achieving its goals (and that is entirely possible given the small dev team) with the fact that the only way it can have the possibility to achieve the goals is to be adequately funded.

As such, while I recommend this, I do so warning all potential buyers that you must accept you're taking a big gamble. You'll get some fun out of the game as it stands right now but it's not complete and frankly may never be the game it deserves to be. The choice is yours and in this case you really are making that risky choice to participate in the Early Access development.

It's also probably worth noting that FPS in the game's current state is pretty poor even with a 1080TI in my system I've seen it drop to 15fps at times and rarely get above 40fps. This is made worse once you start building and laying down automation. Those with medium and low spec systems may want to wait until there is a performance pass on the roadmap or take advantage of the refund system to test it out on your system.
